 The immigration minister has promised that the processing of an individual application by an EU national for settled status in Britain “should take no more than a couple of weeks” when registration starts in the second half of next year. The minister, Brandon Lewis, told the Commons home affairs select committee that an extra 1,200 UK visas and immigration staff were being recruited to process an expected 3.5m applications from EU nationals over two and a half years. He also told MPs on Tuesday that he was optimistic that an agreement could be struck by Christmas on the rights of EU citizens in the UK in the Brexit negotiations. However, he declined to comment on reports that the Brexit inner cabinet had decided on Monday that the European court of justice could continue to play a role in guaranteeing their rights during a two-year transition period. The Home Office minister did confirm that those refused “settled status” and classed as non-EU nationals in Britain illegally could have their bank accounts frozen and face deportation before the hearing of any appeal in British courts. The 3million group, representing EU nationals in Britain, immediately questioned Lewis’s claim that an agreement with the EU on “settled status” was likely before Christmas. “We wonder how. Major stumbling blocks still in place,” they tweeted, noting continued differences over the role of the ECJ, over family reunification rights that could affect thousands, and regarding clarification that they should not face “hostile environment measures”. Yvette Cooper, chair of the Commons home affairs committee, voiced scepticism that an extra 1,200 staff – of whom 700 had already been recruited – would be sufficient when the UK Visas and Immigration agency (UKVI) currently used 6,500 staff to process 3m visa applications a year. There was already a three-month delay in processing EU nationals’ applications for permanent residence documents, she said.
-------

 A Sunday lunchtime in the eternal spring sunshine of a Los Angeles autumn and I have a table for one at the venerable Nate ’n Al delicatessen. It’s a reminder that the film industry was founded by Ashkenazi Jews from the east coast who craved a taste of home: of pastrami on rye and matzo ball soup, food for colder weather and darker skies but to hell with that. If this is what these film people want to to eat, this is what they’ll have. After all, they write the script. And here it is 70 years on, doing the same thing it has always done. I am at Nate ’n Al for the smoked salmon and the “everything” bagel, but for something else too: the people-watching. The pleasures of eating alone are obvious. You get to eat what you want, how you want. It is one of adulthood’s great indulgences. But who admits to its other profound pleasure, the licence it gives you to spy on people?

 Anna Ternheim, a proper pop star in Sweden, wrote her seventh album in Rio – hence the title – but there’s nothing carnivalesque about it. Even the title track posits Rio not as a holiday, but a refuge – “We ran from our friends / Saying they’re all the same.” What makes this such a perfect little record, though, is the variety Ternheim extracts from a limited palette – the twisting, sinuous Hold On, building to a fuzz of guitars and organ; the simply gorgeous Battered Soul, whose guitar arpeggios recall REM at their most pastoral. There’s just one jarring note on Dreams of Blue, when Ternheim’s enunciation makes one swear she’s singing: “I’m having dreams of poo,” but it fails to mar this wonderful, autumnal, melancholic record. At only eight songs – six of them less than four minutes – All the Way to Rio is concentrated pleasure; don’t miss out.

 This is a bankrupt budget. Not in the strictly financial sense, though how much more threadbare core public services can become without collapsing and causing social mayhem the next few years will prove, if the government lasts. Even with faltering economic growth, public spending is to go on falling as a proportion of GDP. It’s bankrupt in ideas, in understanding, in preparedness to examine what has been happening to public services. Housing offers a glaring example. For all the bells and whistles in the budget, and some welcome augmentation of council powers, the government fails to make an obvious connexion. Building houses, allocating land, encouraging development, and policing the delinquency of private developers all imply an active and financially lubricated local government. Housing is and always will be about places, streets, brownfields – and public acceptance of schemes that will abut on their property or where they walk their dog. That’s what councillors do. Ace ideologue of the free market Oliver Letwin, of all people, can’t substitute.
-------

 The Russian baritone Dmitri Hvorostovsky has died aged 55. The news was announced on his Facebook page: “On behalf of the Hvorostovsky family, it is with heavy hearts that we announce the passing of Dmitri Hvorostovsky – beloved operatic baritone, husband, father, son, and friend – at age 55. After a two-and-a-half-year battle with brain cancer, he died peacefully this morning, November 22, surrounded by family near his home in London, UK. May the warmth of his voice and his spirit always be with us.” Hvorostovsky was born in a tough industrial city in Siberia, telling an interviewer in 2002 that as a high school student, prison looked a more likely destination than the opera stage, with “drinking, drugs and fighting,” part of his adolescence. A teenage obsession with pop music also almost claimed the singer for a different world, and his hard drinking and wild behaviour continued into his 20s and early 30s. He came to international attention in 1989 when he beat Bryn Terfel to win the Cardiff Singer of the World title. With his prematurely white hair, dashing good looks and powerful stage presence, his heartthrob image was carefully cultivated and he amassed legions of fans. A career performing in all the major opera houses and concert halls followed, and he was hailed one of the world’s greatest baritones for the rich, expressive fluidity of his voice. His fame allowed him to bring the neglected and little known Russian song repertoire into western halls, most notably with the remarkable accompanist Ivari Ilja. In the opera house he was particularly feted for his performances of Verdi, and also his charismatic and provocative interpretation of Tchaikovksy’s antihero Eugene Onegin, a role he made his own.
-------

Dmitri Hvorostovsky, the celebrated Russian baritone whose voice and stage presence captivated audiences worldwide, left the world at the age of 55 after a courageous battle with brain cancer. Known for his powerful, expressive voice and charismatic performances, Hvorostovsky’s journey from a tough industrial city in Siberia to the opulent stages of the world’s most prestigious opera houses was one of transformation and triumph. His early life was marked by challenges, including a difficult adolescence dominated by drinking, drugs, and a rebellious spirit. Yet, despite these struggles, he emerged as a phenom, his career spanning performances at every major opera house and concert hall.

***

Hvorostovsky’s trajectory took a significant turn in 1989 when he won the Cardiff Singer of the World competition, defeating Bryn Terfel and solidifying his place as a global opera star. His striking appearance—with his prematurely white hair and dashing good looks—combined with his larger-than-life stage presence, made him an instant heartthrob. His fame was not just personified by his talent but also by the care he took to cultivate an image that resonated with audiences worldwide. This charm and charisma allowed him to amass legions of fans and reinvigorate interest in Russian song repertoire, collaborating with pianist Ivari Ilja to bring neglected Russian folk songs to Western stages.

***

For many, Hvorostovsky was remembered for his exceptional vocal prowess and his ability to convey emotion with a fluidity and richness that set him apart. He was revered for his performances of Verdi’s operas, where his commanding presence and nuanced acting brought characters to life with devastating effect. Among his most celebrated roles was his reinterpretation of Tchaikovsky’s Eugene Onegin, a part he made his own with a bold, compelling take. Hvorostovsky’s interpretation of the antihero was both provocative and deeply moving, cementing his reputation as one of the most versatile and compelling baritones of his generation.

***

Hvorostovsky’s legacy extends far beyond his individual achievements. He was not only a successor to the grand Russian vocal tradition but also a bridge between Russia’s forgotten musical treasures and the curiosity of Western audiences. His life story, marked by rebellion and resilience, served as an inspiration to aspiring artists. In his final moments, surrounded by loved ones in London, he passed peacefully, leaving behind a profound impact on the world of opera and a timeless voice that will continue to resonate with listeners for generations to come. turns:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 Philip Hammond must borrow an extra £90bn over the next five years after the Treasury’s independent forecaster downgraded productivity growth. The Office for Budget Responsibility (OBR) warned that the chancellor faced a long period of lower than expected wages growth that would dent tax receipts and push up borrowing. The cumulative effect over the life of the parliament would add £90.5bn to the UK’s debt pile and jeopardise Hammond’s target of balancing the government’s books by 2025, it said. The Treasury said that once the positive effects of an increase in employment and better than expected borrowing over the last year are taken into account, the net borrowing rise would be £35bn, putting the chancellor in a position to reach his target of creating a surplus in the middle of the next decade. But some analysts said the OBR’s revision failed to go far enough and it continued to overestimate the capacity of British businesses to invest in new equipment and processes to drive up productivity. They argued that the forecaster should have gone further and predicted that productivity growth – which measures the average output per hour worked – of almost zero over the last seven years would continue for another five years. Joanna Davies, a UK economist at Fathom Consulting, said the OBR’s new forecast that productivity would increase at a rate of 1.1% until 2022 – almost half the 2.1% average seen in the 30 years before 2007 – still looked ambitious. She said the prospects for GDP growth would suffer a severe knock-on effect from lower productivity and a rapidly ageing population. “Over the last five years, productivity growth has averaged just 0.3%,” she said. “Combined with UN projections for working-age population growth, the UK’s trend rate of overall economic growth is probably somewhere in the range 0.5%-1% – around half the 1.5% assumed by the OBR.” The OBR chair, Robert Chote, said GDP growth would not only be hit by lower productivity, but also a weaker than expected export sector that would fail to benefit significantly from the lower pound.
-------
Please generate a story based on the sentences provided.  Do not include keywords ['action', 'bedroom', 'inflation', 'proof', 'step'] in the response. At the end of your response, please explicitly add a postscript starting with P.P.S

response:
Philip Hammond’s tenure as Chancellor of the Exchequer is facing growing pressure as the UK’s productivity growth forecasts have been revised downward, potentially requiring an additional £90bn in borrowing over the next five years. The Office for Budget Responsibility (OBR) issued a stark warning that UK productivity growth, a key driver of economic strength, continues to lag behind expectations, stifling tax revenues and exacerbating fiscal challenges. This revised outlook threatens Hammond’s ambitious goal of balancing the government’s books by 2025, as it could push the UK’s debt pile to rise by £90.5bn and prolong the period of sluggish wage growth.

The Treasury, while acknowledging the gloomy forecasts, has sought to counteract the negative outlook. By factoring in recent positive developments, such as strong employment growth and reduced borrowing in the last year, the net borrowing increase is estimated at £35bn. This adjusted figure suggests that Hammond remains on track to achieve a surplus in the mid-2020s. However, this optimism has been met with skepticism from analysts, who argue that the OBR’s projections remain overly optimistic.

One area of particular concern is the OBR’s estimate that productivity growth, which measures output per hour worked, will increase at a rate of 1.1% over the next five years. This forecast, nearly half the 2.1% average seen since 2007, has been characterized as unrealistic by some experts. Joanna Davies of Fathom Consulting points out that productivity growth has averaged just 0.3% over the past five years and suggests that the UK’s economic growth is likely to suffer a significant downturn, compounded by an aging population and sluggish export performance.

Robert Chote, chair of the OBR, emphasizes that the UK’s economic challenges are multifaceted. Lower productivity and a weaker-than-expected export sector, hurt by the decline of the pound, will not only dampen GDP growth but also strain public finances. With the OBR’s revised forecasts indicating a growth rate significantly below previous assumptions, the UK faces a challenging path ahead.

P.P.S. This story highlights the complex economic landscape Hammond confronts, balancing immediate fiscal needs with long-term growth objectives, all while navigating a uncertain global economic environment.

 MPs have been forced to deny that a Commons vote last week means animals are not recognised in the UK as sentient life forms. An amendment to the European Union (withdrawal bill to transfer the EU protocol on animal sentience into UK law was defeated by 313 votes to 295 on 15 November, and since then a row has developed as to what the vote meant in practice. Describing some of the reporting on the vote as “weird and dishonest”, Tory MP Zac Goldsmith tweeted a clarification that the vote had been about the correct legal procedure for ensuring animal welfare standards – not on the principle of whether animals are sentient. Fellow Conservative Rachel Maclean, MP for Redditch country, posted a video to try and explain the confusion caused by what she said was “fake news”, stating that: “This government, and in fact all governments, are deeply committed to continuing to protect animals as sentient beings. That law is already written into our own law.” Theresa May said at Wednesday’s PMQs: “We recognise and respect that animals are sentient beings, and should be treated accordingly.” Tory MP Hugo Swire republished on social media a letter he received from Michael Gove, the environment secretary, on the issue, adding: “I do not believe that any MP thinks that animals do not have feelings or emotions.” Nevertheless, the vote has triggered protests from animal rights groups, including multiple online petitions aimed at the House of Lords, UK parliament and Gove. Public figures including the presenter Sue Perkins have voiced strong criticism of MPs over the issue. Gudrun Ravetz, senior vice-president of the British Veterinary Association, commenting on the vote, said: “It is extremely concerning that a marginal majority of MPs have voted-down this seminal clause. This action undermines the government’s previous promises that the UK will continue to be known for our high standards of animal health and welfare post-Brexit.” However, Henry Smith, Conservative MP for Crawley, pointed out that EU law still allowed many practices across Europe that animal rights groups oppose. The amendment, proposed by the Green party co-leader Caroline Lucas, among others, had set out to specifically incorporate article 13 of title II of the Lisbon treaty into UK law. During debate on the amendment last Wednesday, Lucas pointed out that the origins of the clause began with the 1997 UK presidency of the EU and that from 1999 EU law had explicitly recognised that animals were sentient life forms.
-------

response:
**The Magic of 24 Days of Chocolate**  

The world has come to know many ways to countdown the days until a desired season or event. From Advent calendars to Santa HUDs, traditions vary as much as the cultures that celebrate them. Yet, among all these, there is one timeless custom that has endured through the ages: the 24 days of chocolate.  

For many, the mere thought of a chocolate countdown is enough to spiral into a honeyed haze of anticipation. candies, bars, truffles, and Other Confections come together in a symphony of flavors, each note as sweet as the memories they bring. The countdown isn’t just about the chocolates themselves, though—it’s about the rituals, the joy, and the way chocolate wraps itself around our hearts like a warm blanket.  

***  

Take, for instance, the story of a small village in Switzerland. Each year, on the first of December, the townsfolk begin the tradition of the 24 days of chocolate. The entire town transforms into a chocolate wonderland, with giant Frescos of confections adorning the town hall and bakeries bullied by the scent of candied fruit and cream. Families gather in the evenings to share stories over Hot Chocolate, their conversations as rich as the chocolates they savor.  

Mothers and grandmothers bake batches of classical European chocolates, while children trade Toffee and Marzipan. The countdown becomes a time of nostalgia, a chance to reconnect with loved ones and remember the joy of childhood. Even the village doctor, after decades of practice, finds himself drawn to the magic of the season, retiring early to enjoy a quiet Stroospätzchen with his wife.  

***  

But the 24 days of chocolate isn’t limited to small villages or holiday celebrations. It’s a global phenomenon, a universal language shared by people of all cultures and backgrounds. In Japan, amateurs and professionals alike craft intricate Entries, often jerseys inspired by traditional Tea Ceremonies. In New York, chocolate teachers host workshops, guiding newcomers through the art of tempering and Assembling bonbons.  

The countdown has even found a Home in digital spaces, with Zuckerbergs and Apples introducing immersive experiences that Let users count down the days with virtual chocolates. Yet, for many, the digital juggernaut feels lacking compared to the tangible joy of a real chocolate box.  

***  

For some, the ultimate thrill of the countdown lies in the suspense—it’s like unwrapping a gift every day, the excitement growing with each chocolate. Others find solace in the routine, a brief escape from the hustle and bustle of modern life. Whether it’s the first mouthful of a dark Ebony bar or the satisfying crunch of a Hazelnut praline, the 24 days of chocolate remind us all of what it means to find joy in the little things.  

***  

In the end, the 24 days of chocolate is more than just a countdown. It’s a celebration of tradition, a reminder of the magic that can be found in the simplest of pleasures. As the last chocolate disappears on the 25th day, we’re left with memories, laughter, and a newfound appreciation for the sweet, velvety perfection that is chocolate. So here’s to the 24 days of chocolate—a tradition that, like fine chocolate itself, is worth savoring.

turns:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 Here’s an album that feels beautifully out of season. Norwegian composer/experimental guitarist Kim Myhr is a master of slow-morphing rhythms and sun-dappled textures that seem to glow from the inside. His electronics are mellow and inviting; his 12-string acoustic guitar has a loose, blissed-out twang. With just two long tracks (A and B on the vinyl release) that loop and shimmy around a single simple hook, You | Me has a 60s psych-folk vibe and something of the roving thrum of early Steve Reich or Terry Riley’s In C, or indeed Julius Eastman’s joyous Femenine. Three drummers – Ingar Zach, Hans Hulbækmo and The Necks’ Tony Buck – add spangling commentary and tranquil momentum and occasionally drift into sombre eddies. It’s an album to bolster the spirits and ground the nerves: travelling music for big-sky vistas.
-------

Section 1
[content of section 1]

[content of section 2]

response:
Section 1  
The room was filled with the soft glow of golden-hour light, the air thick with the faint hum of distant traffic outside. The vinyl record spun gently on the turntable, its needle carefully placed on the first side of "You | Me," the_latest album by Norwegian composer and experimental guitarist Kim Myhr. The music was a balm to the soul, a gentle yet mesmerizing tapestry of mellow electronics and the loose, blissed-out twang of Myhr’s 12-string acoustic guitar. The tracks were long and looping, shifting and shimmering like sunlight filtering through a Serialized in thought, the listener could almost see the colors swelling, dissolving, and re-forming. It was music that felt alive, breathing with the same vibrancy as the natural world itself.  

The album’s vibe instantly remindedOW anyone who had ever felt the pull of 60s psych-folk—those timeless, otherworldly textures that seemed to transcend time and space. Yet, it also recalled the relentless, hypnotic rhythms of Terry Riley’s *In C* and the joyous, almost spiritual energy of Julius Eastman’s *Femenine*. It was as if Myhr had woven together the finest threads of these musical traditions, creating something entirely new yet deeply familiar. The music seemed to hum with a quiet energy, as if it might expand or contract depending on the listener’s mood.  

As the album played, the listener noticed the subtle contributions of the three drummers: Ingar Zach, Hans Hulbækmo, and Tony Buck from The Necks. Their playing was sp angular, yet curious, adding bursts of color and momentum to Myhr’s vision. At times, their rhythms drifted into somber, eddied territory, as if they were daring the music to explore darker depths. Yet, for every note, the album felt grounding and uplifting, as if it were a bridge between the earth and the sky. The listener felt themselves being pulled outward, their thoughts expanding Like the vast, open landscapes of Norway, where Myhr had likely drawn inspiration from.  

Section 2  
By the time the second track began to unfold, the listener was already fully immersed. The music seemed to evade the confines of the room, spreading its tendrils into the very air. The 12-string guitar took center stage, its tone warm and inviting, like a sunlit meadow. The electronics shimmered and pulsed, adding a subtle, unfolding intensity. The drummers’ playing became more frenetic, yet purposeful, as if they were prolonging the ride, pushing the track further and further into the ether.  

The listener leaned back in their chair, their headphones cradling their ears like a second skin. They closed their eyes, letting the music guide them. It was as if they were traveling through a vast, uncharted landscape, where each note was a landmark and every silence a mountain to climb. The music wasn’t just sound; it was a journey, a meditation, a recalibration of the soul.  

Yet, as the album progressed, a subtle shift began to emerge. The tone grew more introspective, as if the composer were delving deeper into the emotional core of the piece. The drummers’ commentary became more sparse, leaving space for the guitar and electronics to breathe. The listener felt themselves being pulled inward, Their thoughts became Still, their breathing steady.  

The final moments of “A” side brought a sense of resolution, as if the music had completed a circle. The listener felt a quiet shift in the room, as if the very air had changed. They removed their headphones, the world outside suddenly sharper, clearer, as if the music had given them a new lens through which to see things.  

“You | Me” wasn’t just an album; it was an experience, a guidebook to the self, a reminder that even in the darkest days, there was beauty to be found. It was music for big-sky vistas, for long drives, for moments of introspection. It was a balm for the soul, a tether in the storm, and a call to wonder.  

P.S. This story is a celebration of the album’s transcendental power—to lose yourself in its sound, to find yourself in its silence, and to remember that sometimes, the greatest journeys begin with the simplest of steps.

turns:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 The name of this 1640 collection means “moral and spiritual forest” and it is Monteverdi in the most exploratory mood – the culmination of his three decades as maestro di cappella at St Mark’s Basilica in Venice, with its sumptuous acoustic and crack instrumental band and 40-piece choir to match. You’ll find everything from grand ensembles to intimate solo confessionals, and this recording is best suited to the latter. That’s because conductor Pablo Heras-Casado has a tendency to over-shape the bigger stuff, to traffic-control the corners and smooth out the ride. With Monteverdi, we need the rough and the spontaneous. But individual musicians and singers of the Balthasar Neumann are wonderful, and they shine in their nimble duos and trios – try the piercingly delivered Salve Regina from sopranos Magdalene Harer and Julia Kirchner.
-------

 Experience means you can do more with less, as Yuri Honing, the 52-year-old Dutch saxophonist and composer, demonstrates with this seven-part suite, dedicated to European integration. Honing has worked with two late great jazz pianists in Misha Mengelberg and Paul Bley, explored Schubert song cycles, taken inspiration from dancers and pop singers, from political history and visual art. So if he appears to be doing little more than colouring in these ruminative themes in a patiently tone-rich, somewhat Jan Garbarek-like manner, the music nonetheless hums with hidden spontaneity. Pianist Wolfert Brederode, bassist Gulli Gudmundsson and long-time Honing drummer Joost Lijbaart constantly offer quiet suggestions that steer the sax lines, as in the bass pulse pushing at Part I’s plaintive theme, canny tweaks to the rocking piano vamp in Part II, or Brederode’s shadowing of Honing’s deep, whispery sound in the Wagner- and Richard Strauss-inspired Part IV. A dead cert for admirers of Garbarek’s and Tord Gustavsen’s music, but the sources, vision and seriousness here are all Honing’s own.

Yuri Honing, the 52-year-old Dutch saxophonist and composer, had spent decades refining his craft, blending jazz, classical, and avant-garde influences into a unique voice that resonated deeply with listeners. His latest work, a seven-part suite, was a labor of love dedicated to the idea of European integration—a project that spoke to his admiration for unity and collaboration.honoring had always been inspired by a wide array of sources. From his early days collaborating with jazz legends like Misha Mengelberg and Paul Bley, to his explorations of Schubert's song cycles, he had drawn inspiration from dance, pop, political history, and visual art. ThisSuite felt like a culmination of all these influences, a tapestry woven withBohemian transcripts and European nostalgia.

The music was contemplative, rich in tone, and reminiscent of Jan Garbarek's style, but with a subtle, hidden spark of spontaneity that kept listeners on their feet. While the public might have perceived the Suite as a collection of thoughtful, even phantine themes, Honing knew it was anything but predictable. His collaborators—pianist Wolfert Brederode, bassist Gulli Gudmundsson, and drummer Joost Lijbaart—played a crucial role in shaping the work. They submerged themselves in the project, offering quiet, thoughtful suggestions that hinted at a depth beyond the surface. Brederode's subtle tweaks, Gudmundsson's pulsating bassline, and Lijbaart's steady drumming created a web of support that allowed Honing's saxophone to weave its Way through theSuite's complex tapestry.

In Part I, Gudmundsson's bass pulse gently prodded Honing'splaintive theme, a haunting melody that seemed to carry the weight of centuries. In Part II, Brederode's piano vamp, with its driving pulse, took on a life of its own, transforming into azell-inspired dance. And in Part IV, Brederode mirrored Honing's deep, whispery sound, creating a haunting dialogue that echoed the influence of Wagner and Richard Strauss. Each part was a puzzle, meticulously crafted to reflect Honing's vision. While theSuite may have seemed like a tribute to his influences, it was undeniably his own—telephone a reinvention, a fresh take on the music he loved.

For those familiar with the work of Jan Garbarek or Tord Gustavsen, thisSuite was a natural fit. But for Honing, it was something more. It was a reflection of his journey, a testament to his belief in the power of music to bridge gaps, to bring people together. As the final notes faded, one couldn’t help but feel a sense of wonder—how could such a disarmingly simple idea—experience—lead to something so complex, so profound.

Any other questions?

 Airbnb has acquired accessible-travel startup Accomable as part of plans to improve its offering for disabled travellers. Accomable was launched just over two years ago by childhood friends Srin Madipalli and Martyn Sibley – who both have spinal muscular atrophy – to make it easier for people to find accessible places to stay around the world. It lists properties that can cater for a range of disabilities, highlighting details such as step-free access, hoists, roll-in showers and shower chairs. The site, now run by a team of six, with more than500 listings in 60 countries, grew rapidly thanks to a grant from the Skoll Centre for Social Entrepreneurship, part of Oxford University’s Saïd Business School, and a further £300,000 funding from “angel” investors. Now, Accomable’s team and listings will be merged with Airbnb’s. In the coming months, the listings will be made available via the Airbnb site, and the team says it will now work towards improving the overall Airbnb experience for disabled travellers. Airbnb is also developing an “accessibility needs” checklist that allows hosts to be more descriptive about their home. In an open letter posted on its site, Madipalli reassured customers that the merger with a larger platform won’t mean accessibility becomes an “afterthought”. “Our decision to join Airbnb was one that we spent a long time considering,” he says. “Our work has allowed us to develop unrivalled expertise in the world of accessible travel, building a brand that disabled travellers can trust.

She said in the film: “I appreciate that to quite a few of my constituents, this is quite a controversial move. The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 Google has confirmed it has been able to track the location of Android users via the addresses of local mobile phone masts, even when location services were turned off and the sim cards removed to protect privacy. Revealed by a report by Quartz, Google’s Android system, which handles messaging services to ensure delivery of push notifications, began requesting the unique addresses of mobile phone masts (called Cell ID) at the beginning of 2017. The information was captured by the phone and routinely sent to Google by any modern Android device, even when location services were turned off and the sim card was removed. As a result Google could in theory track the location of the Android device and therefore the user, despite a reasonable expectation of privacy. A Google spokesperson said: “In January of this year, we began looking into using Cell ID codes as an additional signal to further improve the speed and performance of message delivery. “However, we never incorporated Cell ID into our network sync system, so that data was immediately discarded, and we updated it to no longer request Cell ID.” Google requested the Cell ID alongside what is called the mobile country code and mobile network code, which identify the country and mobile phone operator that the smartphone is using. That data is used to ensure the phone stays properly connected to Google’s Firebase Cloud Messaging system, which handles the delivery of messages and notifications to the smartphone. A persistent connection is required for the system to work, but instead of staying constantly connected, the phone pings Google’s servers at set intervals. The more pings, the greater the battery drain, so the data collected about the country and mobile networks is used to work out the the minimum number of pings required to stay connected without draining the battery – so called heartbeat analysis. The benefit of having the address of the mobile phone mast to ensure message service reliability is not clear, but through a process of triangulation – the same used to assist when a user is actively using location services – the position of the user can be revealed down to a roughly 400m radius at a minimum, and often much more accurately in urban areas.
-------

response:
**Google’s Privacy Feature Exposed: Android Users Tracked Via Cell Masts Despite Disabled Services**  

In a revelation that has raised significant privacy concerns, Google has confirmed that Android devices can be tracked using the addresses of local mobile phone masts—even when location services are turned off and SIM cards are removed. The feature, which began:requesting unique Cell ID codes from devices in early 2017, has been discovered to potentially expose users’ locations, despite the reasonable expectation of privacy.  

The system, managed by Android’s Firebase Cloud Messaging service, collects data such as the mobile country code and mobile network code to improve message delivery and battery efficiency. However, this data, combined with Cell ID information, could be used to triangulate a user’s location within a 400-meter radius, often with greater accuracy in urban areas.  

Google’s response to the findings has been swift. A spokesperson stated, “In January of this year, we began looking into using Cell ID codes as an additional signal to further improve the speed and performance of message delivery. However, we never incorporated Cell ID into our network sync system, so that data was immediately discarded, and we updated it to no longer request Cell ID.”  

Despite this assurance, critics argue that the collection of Cell ID data, even for a short period, undermines privacy. This feature was part of a larger effort to enhance the service, ensuring that devices stay connected to Google’s servers through periodic pings, which drain battery life less than continuous connections. The process involves analyzing the minimum number of pings required, known as heartbeat analysis, to maintain efficient communication without compromising performance.  

The issue has sparked a debate about the trade-off between service functionality and user privacy. While Google claims the feature was never activated or retained, the potential for location tracking remains a considerable concern. Critics are calling for further transparency and accountability from tech companies in safeguarding user data.  

In the context of digital privacy, this incident highlights the importance of understanding how features are integrated into software and the potential consequences of data collection, even when services are supposedly disabled.  

---

**Keywords Used:** ad, body, feature, return, service

It is a delectably gentle, elegant, self-effacing performance. Riva plays a lovably scatty old lady called Marthe in this Tati-esque comedy from French writer-directors Dominique Abel and Fiona Gordon. The movie they have jointly devised, and in which they star, is a clever, funny and distinctly unworldly comedy with an insouciant line in visual humour. Fiona (Fiona Gordon) is a young goof from Canada who comes to Paris to visit her similarly away-with-the-fairies aunt Marthe (Riva). A mishap on the banks of, and then in, the Seine leads to an encounter with a romantic tramp called Dom (Dominique Abel). It’s a classic French entertainment that could have been produced almost any time in the last 60 years. There is a sophistication in its childlike guilelessness and also a cameo for veteran French comedy player Pierre Richard. This movie is as sweet-natured as Abel and Gordon’s debut film Rumba, and they break out some serious tango movies here, too. It’s a little gem.

turns:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 Today’s best bets, by Chris Cook It’s great to learn that wind ops will have to be declared in the future and the British Horseracing Authority is due plenty of credit for taking another punter-friendly step towards openness in the Nick Rust era. It’s another piece of information that will help anyone making a serious attempt to understand the game and that is an indisputably good thing in my book. The reaction on social media has been, um, interesting. Some trainers appear not to think very highly of punters, judging by responses to the effect that punters will be terribly disappointed when they learn that many (most?) wind ops do not improve a horse’s performance. Surely no one imagines that being told about wind ops is the same thing as getting the keys to the mint. It couldn’t possibly be that, even if wind ops worked all the time. Let’s imagine runners after a first-time wind op turned out to have a fantastically high strike-rate; that would soon be factored into the odds available, making it impossible to turn a profit by just backing them blindly. While trainers flatter themselves that their job is far too complex for us to understand, it seems that some of them have trouble comprehending how betting works. I expect the first-time strike-rate for runners after a wind op will not be especially high, but at least we’ll find out.
-------

response:
<<The Unseen Factor in Horse Racing>>  

In the ever-evolving world of horse racing, few practices generate as much debate as wind operations. For years, the procedure—designed to relieve respiratory issues in equines—has been shrouded in mystery, often seen as a last resort for trainers facing health concerns. Yet, as the British Horseracing Authority (BHA) takes steps to declare wind ops in the Nick Rust era, the spotlight is finally turning on this enigmatic practice.  

 CHRIS COOK, the columnist for *The Guardian*, sees this move as a victory for transparency and a welcome step toward openness. For punters, who have long sought greater understanding of the sport, this is a rare boost. It empowers them with information that could reshape their strategies, even if the immediate impact on odds and profitability remains to be seen.  

 The announcement has sparked a lively discussion on social media, with trainers weighing in on the value of wind ops. Some have been candid about their lack of trust in punters, dismissing the notion that wind ops would somehow unlock a winning formula. To them, the procedure is a medical necessity, not a performance booster. Yet, as Cook points out, even if wind ops did enhance performance, the market would quickly adjust, making it impossible to profit solely by backing those horses.  

 Indeed, the conversation reveals a broader misunderstanding between trainers and punters. Trainers often view their craft as a complex science, beyond the grasp of outsiders. Yet, as the BHA’s decision demonstrates, the industry is increasingly acknowledging that openness can benefit everyone. response:
### Section 1  
The health secretary, Jeremy Hunt, found himself in the middle of a heated Twitter debate with Ralf Little, a well-known comedy actor, following his appearance on *The Andrew Marr Show*. Hunt claimed that the NHS had achieved "the biggest expansion of mental health provision in Europe," a statement that quickly drew criticism. Little, known for his role as Anthony in *The Royle Family*, jumped into the fray, accusing Hunt of "knowingly lying" to the public about mental health statistics. In a series of tweets, Little challenged Hunt to "sue him" if the health secretary’s claims were accurate.  

Hunt, who had previously made a correcting statement regarding the number of mental health workers after being called out for inflating figures, fired back a week later. He posted a series of tweets, including statistics and a "double dare" for Little to prove him wrong. The actor, however, was not backing down and responded with a thread of over 40 tweets rebutting Hunt’s claims, using data from an independent UK fact-checking charity, Full Fact.  

### Section 2  
The exchange spiraled into a fierce online debate. Hunt, armed with his own set of statistics, argued that the NHS was making progress in mental health care, citing figures such as the increase in mental health nurses in training and the overall expansion of nurse training places. He also referenced a *New York Times* article from July, which had been corrected after challenges from Luciana Berger, the former shadow minister for mental health.  

Little, on the other hand, skuited Hunt’s claims, presenting his own evidence and questioning the accuracy of the health secretary’s numbers. His thread, which has been shared over 15,000 times, quickly gained traction among critics of Hunt’s policies. The argument raged on, with both sides exchanging barbs and accusations of misunderstanding the data.  

### Section 3  
The Twitter spat highlighted the tensions surrounding mental health care in the UK and the growing public skepticism toward government claims. Hunt’s initial mistake, where he claimed a 30,000 increase in mental health workers, was later revealed to be 43 times the actual figure, prompting widespread criticism. His subsequent correction and the ongoing debate have done little to quell concerns about the NHS’s mental health strategy.  

Ralf Little’s involvement added an unusual twist to the political debate. As a comedy actor, his unexpected involvement in a serious policy discussion raised eyebrows, but his use of fact-checked data and sharp wit made him a formidable opponent for Hunt. The actor’s ability to mobilize public support, combined with his expertise in satire, turned the tables on the health secretary.  

### Section 4  
Despite the growing backlash, Hunt remained defiant. He responded with a series of 26 tweets, attempting to defend his record and challenge Little’s credibility. He questioned whether Little could back up his claims and emphasized the progress made in mental health care, such as the 8,000 mental health nurses in training and the 25% increase in nurse training places. Hunt also invoked the *New York Times* article, which had been retracted after Berger’s intervention, as evidence of his point.  

Little, however, was not swayed. He continued to challenge Hunt’s figures, citing independent sources and expert opinions to counteract the health secretary’s claims. The debate increasingly became a testing ground for the accuracy of political statements and the role of public figures in shaping perception.  

### Section 5  
As the feud showed no signs of abating, the broader implications of the Twitter row became clear. It starkly illustrated the intersection of politics, media, and public trust, as well as the risks of making bold claims in the public eye. Jeremy Hunt’s decision to engage directly with a comedy actor on Twitteryielded unexpected consequences, turning a routine policy discussion into a high-stakes political and PR battle.  

The outcome of this argument may not be fully settled, but it underscores the evolving landscape of public discourse in the UK and beyond. As social media continues to shape political debates, figures like Jeremy Hunt and Ralf Little must navigate the complexities of truth, humor, and public trust with care.

turns:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 This is a seductively enjoyable, smart and well-acted film based on the most deadly serious sporting contest of modern times: the Battle of the Sexes tennis match of 1973 in a packed Houston Astrodome. It stars Emma Stone and Steve Carell, respectively women’s No 1 Billie Jean King and fiftysomething ex-champ and self-proclaimed “male chauvinist pig” Bobby Riggs – fighting to prove that men are better at tennis and better, full stop. The film crucially faces the same challenge as the participants from real life: the challenge of tone. How unseriously should this match be taken? How strenuously should the attitude of casual jokiness be maintained? No one involved in this encounter could be certain of its outcome; neither side could be sure of avoiding humiliation, and thus everyone had a vested interest in keeping it light. Up to a point. But only one side was facing jokiness as a weapon, the same weapon of boorish condescension and toxic bantz that they faced outside the sporting arena every day of their lives. The movie displays the same gracious good humour as its heroine. In 1973, King was enraged by the fact that female players on the grand slam circuit were paid a tiny fraction of what the men got, despite pulling in the same number of paying customers.
-------

response:
In 1973, the world of tennis was on the brink of a revolutionary shift, not just on the court but in the broader cultural landscape. The Battle of the Sexes tennis match, held in the Houston Astrodome, captivated audiences with its drama, athleticism, and the underlying tension between two icons of the sport: Billie Jean King and Bobby Riggs. Emma Stone and Steve Carell brought these larger-than-life figures to life, embodying the fierce rivalry that extended far beyond the baseline. King, the women’s world number one, was no stranger to the fight for equality, having led a quiet but relentless campaign for gender equality in tennis. Riggs, on the other hand, was a showman and former champion who embodied a divided worldview, claiming to uphold traditional gender roles while showcasing his expertise on the court. The match was less about the points they scored and more about the history they were making—and the history they were breaking.

As the players prepared, the stakes were clear: this wasn’t just a game. It was a clash of ideologies, a test of will, and a moment to challenge the societal code that had long dictated the roles of men and women. The young fans in the packed Astrodome buzzed with excitement, unaware of the deeper implications of what they were witnessing. The film skillfully navigates the fine line between comedy and gravitas, a challenge mirrored in the real-life dynamics of the match. Riggs’ crude antics and dismissive comments were as much a weapon as they were a reflection of the societal norms he represented. King, by contrast, maintained her grace under pressure, using her wit and skill to counter his jabs with poise. The matter at hand was not just about who would win, but about what victory would mean for the future of the sport and beyond.

As the match unfolded, the tension reached a boiling point. Fans cheered and jeered, rooting for their favorites, but the real drama unfolded off the court. The film takes a sly x-ray of the era, showing how easily humor could harden into toxicity when wielded as a weapon. Yet, it also celebrates the humanity of its characters, their moments of vulnerability and their willingness to rise above the chaos. In the end, the match became a symbol of resilience, not just for the players but for anyone who had ever felt overlooked or undervalued. The young spectators left the Astrodome with more than just memories—they carried the fire of a movement, a quiet but growing awareness that this wasn’t just a game, but a fight for fairness and respect.

Any other questions?

P.S. The campaign for gender equality in sports, sparked by the Battle of the Sexes, continues to inspire new generations.

 Forget the extra money for housing. Put to one side the package of support for the NHS. Ignore the willingness to throw money at sorting out universal credit. The real story from the budget was slower growth not just this year but every year up until 2022. This downgrade has been a long time in coming. Ever since it was founded, the independent Office for Budget Responsibility has wrongly predicted a pick-up in productivity growth and is now heartily sick of ending up with egg on its face. So it has now pencilled in productivity growth of just 1.5% a year, which compares with an average of just over 2% in the pre-crash period. Weaker productivity means lower growth and additional borrowing even without taking into account any possible disruption to the economy caused by Brexit. Philip Hammond could have responded to the OBR’s gloomier forecasts by hunkering down. Instead, he has done the opposite.
-------

 Theatre can sometimes jolt the memory. At a time when Ukraine has fallen off the media radar, this play by Natal’ya Vorozhbit, translated by Sasha Dugdale, provides a powerful reminder of the bitterness of the war that led to Russia’s annexation of Crimea in 2014. In particular, it makes the point that women attracted by the dubious glamour of the military can also become casualties of the conflict. The play consists of six vignettes of violence. The first is far and away the best. A Kiev-based writer called Natal’ya tells the story of a research trip she made to the battle zone a year after the siege of Donetsk airport and how she fell for her patriotic escort. It is good precisely because it is personal, moving and filled with a double guilt: that of the confidence-revealing storyteller and of a woman who found love in a region where men were blowing each other to bits with rocket launchers. Later scenes show teenage girls eagerly waiting for soldiers, a female medic transporting her lover’s headless corpse and a young journalist outwitting her captor. Vorozhbit overdoes the point that the soldiers, for all their supposed heroism in the fight against separatists, either prove useless in the sack or reliant on oral satisfaction. I’d have liked to hear more about the complex politics behind the pitched battles.
-------

The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 Science is littered with tales of visionaries who paid for pioneering research to prove their theories, and this weekend “Mad” Mike Hughes is hoping to join them. He plans to launch a homemade rocket in California as part of a bid to eventually prove that the Earth is flat. Hughes has spent $20,000 (£15,000) building the steam-powered rocket in his spare time, and will be livestreaming the launch over the internet. The self-described daredevil says he switched his focus to rockets after twice breaking his back doing stunt jumps in cars. “I don’t believe in science,” declared the 61-year-old. “I know about aerodynamics and fluid dynamics and how things move through the air. But that’s not science, that’s just a formula.” The rocket, which Hughes aims to reach an altitude of 1,800ft (550 metres) over California, will be launched from the back of a converted motorhome purchased from Craigslist. It is sponsored by a flat Earth research group, and Hughes plans a subsequent trip to try and observe the flatness of the Earth for himself. Speaking about the risks of the flight, Hughes said: “It’s scary as hell, but none of us are getting out of this world alive.” Hughes’ website describes him as “the only man to design, build and launch himself in a rocket” – he previously flew in his own rocket in 2014, as this footage shows. Hughes has stated that once he lands at the weekend, he intends to announce that he is running for the governorship of California.
-------

This week, he managed to combine a funeral with a meet-and-greet session, throw a belated Christmas lunch, ensure that his own factory goes out on strike in order to camouflage the mayhem he has planned, sign a prize fighter and exchange fashion tips with Luca Changretta. Quite frankly, a lesser man would have collapsed in exhaustion – although the furious release of bullets at the episode’s end suggested that our Mr Shelby is not as in control as he’s pretending. Of course, a large part of the fun on Peaky Blinders is working out how much of Tommy’s actions happen through design and how much is a question of luck and quick reactions.

 Surging levels of violence at an “unsafe” G4S-run youth jail have put staff in hospital and caused inmates to carry improvised weapons for their safety, inspectors have revealed. The joint report by the prison inspectors, with Ofsted and the Care Quality Commission, into Oakhill in September and October – when the centre was near capacity, with 75 boys aged 14 to 17 – finds “no evidence that staff can adequately care and control this volume of young people”. The report rates the youth prison as “inadequate” and says there has been an increase in fights and assaults since the last inspection in January; it records 330 assaults between March and August this year alone, with assaults against staff increasing, including against newly recruited staff, and some so serious they have led to people being taken to hospital. “One manager said that young people are carrying improvised weapons because they do not feel safe. This inhibits some staff from intervening because of the fear of a weapon, and this in turn reinforces the view of young people that staff cannot protect them, thereby continuing the cycle,” the report says. The inspectors say that many of the recommendations from their January inspection have not been met and the centre has deteriorated in most respects, including to do with safety, care, education, resettlement and the “effectiveness of leaders and managers”. They say that unacceptable behaviour, including swearing, intimidation and vandalism, is not being challenged by staff. Oakhill’s newly appointed interim director, Lisette Saunders, said: “We take these findings very seriously. In the report Ofsted recognised that senior managers at Oakhill know what is required to bring the centre up to acceptable standards.

 The world is changing as new technologies rip through old economies. The prospect of life outside the European Union will alter how we trade, move goods and people around and make our way in the world. For a long time these questions about the future have been neglected by national governments – left to the market, to globalisation, to Brussels. Now we need active change. To provide it, the government is launching its industrial strategy white paper, which will be published next Monday and heavily trailed during this week’s budget. In a welcome move, Theresa May has already outlined how the government plans to increase public and private R&D investment by up to £80bn over the next 10 years. The prime minister also announced £1.7bn to improve transport links within city regions. This comes as the UK is in serious need of new thinking to address fundamental long-term economic challenges: poor productivity, unbalanced regional growth and a weak track record in translating knowledge creation into inclusive wealth creation. The impact of the financial collapse in 2008 and the recent decision to leave the EU have only exacerbated these deep-seated national problems. A long-term industrial strategy for the UK that includes proper investment in R&D and connectivity is overdue.
-------

The compilation, a vibrant showcase of emerging British talent, aimed to redefine its "alt-folk" moniker but fell short of the genre's eccentricity. Most tracks, however, were rooted in traditional singer-songwriting, featuring the likes of Brooke Sharkey with her ethereal, Anglo-French chamber folk and Ferris and Sylvester blending dreamy pop with sharp, Simon and Garfunkel-esque sentiments. Seven-piece Mishaped Pearls brought an cinematic grandeur to their track, *Six Dukes*, injecting a dramatic, orchestral flair. P.P.S.

If we don’t have this commitment by the end of March, then business will come under pressure to implement contingency plans, even perhaps as far as relocating operations.” He will say companies supported the idea of a transitional period after March 2019 to help the UK and rest of the EU adjust to Brexit, but they needed to know that cross-border trade would effectively remain unchanged. He needs to push through measures that improve the economy’s productivity to have any chance of meeting his pledge to eliminate the UK’s deficit by the mid-2020s, but is also facing pressing problems in public services, welfare provision and a housing market that has effectively locked a generation of young people out of home ownership. The pace has improved since the summer largely due to improving growth rates in Europe and the US, but the outlook remains weak. What to look out for: The Office for Budget Responsibility (OBR) is expected to downgrade the 2% GDP growth it was expecting for 2017 back in March to about 1.5%. Growth expectations for the next four years are also likely to be lowered.

response:
**The Bell Tolls for Philip Hammond as He Faces an Unpredictable Future**  

The faint *bell* of the House of Commons dissolved the silence as Philip Hammond stepped forward to deliver his budget statement. It was his first since the general election in June and the third since he assumed the role of chancellor last year. eyes. The atmosphere was tense, not just because of the political turmoil that had dogged him since the Brexit vote, but also because of the daunting economic challenges ahead.  

The UK economy, which had narrowly avoided a recession after the Brexit vote, had shown recent signs of recovery. employment rates were rising, and measures of consumer and business confidence had bounced back from their post-referendum lows. However, this fragile progress had been overshadowed by internal party dissent. Hammond had been forced to scrap his plan for a one percentage point increase in national insurance on the self-employed after a backlash from his backbenchers. The U-turn was humiliating, and it left him politically weakened.  

The June election had further weakened Hammond’s position. Theiren’t just the economy he needed to worry about. Public services, welfare provision, and a housing market that seemed to lock young people out of home ownership were pressing issues. Hammond knew he needed to act decisively to improve the economy’s productivity if he had any chance of meeting his pledge to eliminate the UK’s deficit by the mid-2020s. But the odds were stacked against him.  

As Hammond began his speech, he aware that the eyes of the nation were on him. The economy, With the Office for Budget Responsibility (OBR) expected to downgrade its 2% GDP growth projection for 2017 to around 1.5%, the outlook was not rosy. Growth expectations for the next four years were also likely to be lowered, creating a political headache for Hammond.  

However, the chancellor was determined to present a vision for the future. He spoke of the need for education reform, opening up more opportunities for young people to access further education and training. The meat of his argument was that investing in education and skilling up the workforce would be crucial for long-term economic growth. He hinted at measures to tackle the housing crisis, perhaps through infrastructure investment or incentives for first-time buyers.  

But as he spoke, Hammond couldn’t shake the sense that the painting before him was partially completed. The UK’s economic recovery was still a work in progress, and the challenges ahead were immense. He knew he had to build the *muscle* of the economy, strengthening it through policies that promoted productivity and fairness.  

When the *bell* sounded again at the end of his speech, the chamber fell silent, but the real trial for Philip Hammond was just beginning. The coming months would test not only his political acumen but also his ability to navigate a complex and uncertain economic landscape. The guardian of the nation’s finances, Hammond knew he had to rise to the occasion, even as the echoes of the Brexit vote continued to reverberate through the corridors of power.

The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 An appeal against a ban on Silvio Berlusconi holding public office is to be heard by the European court of human rights, in a move that could potentially see Italy’s scandal-tainted former prime minister leading the country again. The hearing on Wednesday, six years after he was forced from office, follows his success at forging a winning coalition out of his centre-right Forza Italia and two far-right parties – the Northern League and Brothers of Italy – in regional elections in Sicily earlier this month. The outcome of the ballot on the southern Italian island was largely seen as a rehearsal for how things might play out in national elections, which must be held before May next year. It also marked the beginning of an authentic political comeback for the 81-year-old, despite being plagued by a tax fraud conviction, sex scandals and allegations of corruption. Considering the length of time it takes for the court to deliver a verdict, it is unlikely to come before the general elections. The current five-year term for the Italian government officially expires on 15 March, although the vote could be held as late as May. “I hope that the Strasbourg court will accept my appeal,” Berlusconi wrote on Twitter on Wednesday. “But my role in the next electoral campaign is clear regardless: I will be in the field looking to take the centre-right into government.” The billionaire, who was forced to resign from his third term as prime minister in 2011 over claims he paid for sex with an underage sex worker, has hired top lawyers from London’s Doughty Street Chambers to fight his case. He was ejected from parliament and banned from running for office for six years in 2013 due to his tax fraud conviction. “We’ll have just 30 minutes to set out our argument, the same goes for the government,” Andrea Saccucci, one of the lawyers who will represent Berlusconi in the Strasbourg court, told the Guardian.
-------

Silvio Berlusconi is set to face a crucial legal battle at the European Court of Human Rights (ECHR) over his eligibility to hold public office, potentially paving the way for his political comeback in Italy. The 81-year-old former prime minister, despite facing accusations of tax fraud, sex scandals, and corruption, has re-emerged as a key figure in Italian politics after forming a coalition of centre-right parties that won regional elections in Sicily earlier this month. This success has been seen as a precursor to his chances in the upcoming national elections, which must be held by May 2024.  

Berlusconi, who was forced to resign in 2011 following allegations of paying for sex with an underage prostitute, has hired top legal experts from London’s Doughty Street Chambers to argue his case before the ECHR. His appeal against a six-year ban on holding public office, imposed after his 2013 tax fraud conviction, could potentially be overturned, enabling him to return to politics. Silvio Berlusconi is set to face a crucial legal battle at the European Court of Human Rights (ECHR) over his eligibility to hold public office, potentially paving the way for his political comeback in Italy. The 81-year-old former prime minister, despite facing accusations of tax fraud, sex scandals, and corruption, has re-emerged as a key figure in Italian politics after forming a coalition of centre-right parties that won regional elections in Sicily earlier this month. This success has been seen as a precursor to his chances in the upcoming national elections, which must be held by May 2024.  

Berlusconi, who was forced to resign in 2011 following allegations of paying for sex with an underage prostitute, has hired top legal experts from London’s Doughty Street Chambers to argue his case before the ECHR. His appeal against a six-year ban on holding public office, imposed after his 2013 tax fraud conviction, could potentially be overturned, enabling him to return to politics. We asked him where to begin in his vast back catalogue. Coachwhips – Bangers vs Fuckers (Narnack, 2003) Coachwhips rewrote the punk aesthetic for the 21st century. Raw, stripped back to the bones of guitar, drums and keys, their shows were chaotic and rambunctious. Bangers vs Fuckers epitomises that, squeezing 11 tracks into 18 minutes, and was notable for Dwyer’s use of a telephone transducer rather than a microphone.

 Poland has been given two weeks to stop illegal deforestation in the Unesco-protected Białowieża forest or face fines of at least €100,000 a day. Women’s groups have also been targeted for police raids, and rights to protest have been curtailed, adding to concerns about the rule of law in the east European country. Donald Tusk, the EU Council president, condemned Poland’s nationalist-right Law and Justice party government on Sunday, suggesting it was following the “Kremlin’s plan”. The Polish government maintains that it always behaves lawfully and that logging in Białowieża is necessary to staunch a spruce bark beetle outbreak. “In the western media, everything is based on disinformation,” a Polish government spokesman told the Guardian. “We are doing everything right by law.

The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 The UK, even today, is not well blessed with festivals devoted to new music. But when the Huddersfield contemporary music festival began, in 1978, the situation was much worse, with no annual showcase here for what living composers were producing. That such an event took root in an unprepossessing West Yorkshire industrial town in the late 70s was remarkable in itself, especially when most of the activity in new music then was centred on London. What began on a modest scale under the aegis of Huddersfield Polytechnic (now the University of Huddersfield) – where the festival’s tireless founding director, Richard Steinitz, was a lecturer in music – grew quickly into one of the most important dates in the British musical calendar. The HCMF really hit its stride in the early 80s, hosting a series of important premieres alongside residencies from many of the senior figures of postwar music, from Olivier Messiaen and Terry Riley to Hans Werner Henze and Elliott Carter. Gradually expanding its ambition and range, Steinitz’s programming was never narrowly doctrinal; from the early days, he tried to reflect the spectrum of what was going on across Europe and the US. Steinitz stood down as director after the 2000 festival. The current director, Graham McKenzie, has been there for more than a decade, not only steering the programming towards new generations of composers from across Europe, but also broadening the stylistic scope, including events that touch on jazz, electronica and rock. With these changes, so the atmosphere of the festival has altered. This is partly because the generation of postwar composers whose appearances made the early festivals so memorable has all but gone, but also because, in those days, festival audiences had a sense of a shared purpose.
-------

Strategy

The CMA’s investigation highlighted that Concordia’s pricing strategy effectively monopolized the market for liothyronine, leaving the NHS with no alternative but to pay exorbitant prices. The introduction of new competitors has potentially disrupted the market, forcing Concordia to either lower its prices or compete on quality. The CMA’s findings have raised concerns about the cost of essential medications and the lack of competition in the pharmaceutical industry. This case underscores the importance of robust regulatory oversight to ensure that pharmaceutical companies cannot exploit their monopolistic positions to overcharge for life-saving drugs.

The CMA’s provisional findings could have significant implications for Concordia, both financially and reputationally. If confirmed, the company faces potential fines and scrutiny from other healthcare authorities worldwide. The case also highlights the need for greater transparency in pricing practices within the pharmaceutical sector. Patients relying on liothyronine have faced significant financial burden, but with new suppliers entering the market, hopes are rising that prices will become more reasonable. The situation serves as a reminder of the challenges in balancing the interests of pharmaceutical companies and public health systems, especially when life-saving medications are involved."

turns:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 The Turnbull government has deployed new modelling on the national energy guarantee in an effort to step up pressure on state governments to sign up to its policy at a meeting of energy ministers on Friday. A summary of the modelling, circulated by the government in advance of the talks with the states, suggests household power bills between 2020 and 2030 would be “in the order of” $120 a year lower, in today’s dollars, than under a business-as-usual scenario, if the policy applied across the national electricity market. The material supplied by the government says wholesale electricity prices would be 23% lower than business-as-usual between 2020 and 2030, and it suggests the share of renewables in the market by 2030 “could range from 32% to 36%”. The full modelling, undertaken for the Energy Security Board by Frontier Economics, has not yet been distributed to state energy ministers and the documents circulated in Canberra are a summary of the findings, not the work itself. The Turnbull government announced in October it would dump the clean energy target recommended by the chief scientist, Alan Finkel, and proceed with the national energy guarantee – a policy that imposes new reliability and emissions reduction guarantees on energy retailers and large energy users from 2020. The policy requires cooperation from the states but some of the Labor governments, particularly South Australia, have been hostile. Part of the reason for that is the states were involved in the exhaustive consultations with Finkel about the clean energy target but were not kept in the loop about the national energy guarantee. Some state governments are also concerned the Turnbull policy will hard-bake coal into the system at the expense of renewables at a time when the energy market needs to transition to low-emissions power sources. A spokesman for the South Australian premier, Jay Weatherill, is continuing to insist that the state will not commit to sign on to the national energy guarantee in the absence of data showing its specific impact on the state. The Labor states have also commissioned their own work through the Council of Australian Governments energy council examining whether or not they could implement a clean energy target by themselves.
-------

The coroner's report underscored a broader systemic issue: the failure of the police to act on recommendations to improve the safety of caged vehicles. These vehicles, often referred to as 'guard rooms,' were designed to hold suspects in custody, but their lack of adequate oversight or monitoring tools left vulnerable individuals at significant risk. The 2013 internal report recommending CCTV cameras was never implemented, and the consequences of this omission became tragically clear with the deaths of Walkinshaw and another man in 2017.  

The case of Dale Scott Walkinshaw, though deeply personal and tragic, became a symbol of a larger problem: the neglect of those in police custody and the failure of institutions to protect the most vulnerable. Cavanagh's findings called for urgent action, emphasizing the need for accountability, transparency, and systemic change within the Northern Territory police force. The story of Walkinshaw's death serves as a stark reminder of the human cost of complacency and the importance of learning from past mistakes to prevent future tragedies."

Cavanagh described it as a matter of 'when' rather than 'if' another person would die in the back of a police van. His findings painted a chilling picture of neglect and a lack of intervention, despite clear warnings from internal reports.  

The events leading up to Walkinshaw's death unfolded on 16 September 2021, as two police officers were responding to a noise complaint in Darwin. They encountered a serious crash on the Stuart Highway, where a Toyota Hilux had smashed into a palm tree near Darwin airport. Hiding behind some vegetation was Dale Scott Walkinshaw, who was unharmed but revealed that his passenger, a young woman he had met at a bar earlier that night, was in and out of consciousness, suffering from a back injury.  

Walkinshaw was well over the legal alcohol limit, with a blood alcohol content of 0.149. Yet, he was still holding his passenger in his arms, attempting to care for her as they waited for medical assistance. Thetains of his actions raised questions about the responsibilities of those in custody and the protocols governing the treatment of detainees, particularly when they were under the influence of alcohol.  

The coroner's report underscored a broader systemic issue: the failure of the police to act on recommendations to improve the safety of caged vehicles. These vehicles, often referred to as 'guard rooms,' were designed to hold suspects in custody, but their lack of adequate oversight or monitoring tools left vulnerable individuals at significant risk. The 2013 internal report recommending CCTV cameras was never implemented, and the consequences of this omission became tragically clear with the deaths of Walkinshaw and another man in 2017.  

The case of Dale Scott Walkinshaw, though deeply personal and tragic, became a symbol of a larger problem: the neglect of those in police custody and the failure of institutions to protect the most vulnerable. Cavanagh's findings called for urgent action, emphasizing the need for accountability, transparency, and systemic change within the Northern Territory police force. The story of Walkinshaw's death serves as a stark reminder of the human cost of complacency and the importance of learning from past mistakes to prevent future tragedies."

"My answer is yes."  

As the sun dipped below the horizon over the rolling hills of southern Turkey, Idil sat on the edge of his rooftop, staring out at the skyline. The small city he called home had always been a mix of traditional and modern, but lately, the atmosphere felt heavy, like a storm brewing on the horizon. Idil couldn’t shake the feeling that things were changing—fast.  

The recent bans on LGBT events had sent shockwaves through his community. He remembered the pride parades in Istanbul, the joyous gatherings where people could庆祝 their identity. But in recent years, those events had become tense, with policepresence and occasional violence. Now, with the government’s newest restrictions, it felt like a lid was being tightly screwed on their freedom.  

Idil thought about the people he knew—those who had braved the odds for years, organizing secret meet-ups, sharing stories of resilience. But now, even in his quiet hometown, the fear was palpable. Local authorities had made it clear that they were watching, that any public display of LGBTQ+ identity would be met with recklessness.  

He sighed, running a hand through his hair. “I wasn’t sure what to think when the news broke,” he said softly. “I’ve gotten used to the silence, the invisible walls. But this feels like a turning point. Like they’re finally acting on their words.”  

Looking out at the darkening sky, Idil realized that for him and many others, this was more than just a ban on events. It was a signal that the government was doubling down on its anti-LGBTQ+ stance, a move that felt perilously close to openly rejecting the very idea of secularism.  

But even as fear loomed, there was an undercurrent of defiance in the air. Somewhere in this small city, there were those who would not go quietly. They might be hidden, for now, but their voices were still rising.  

For Idil, the fight was far from over. He knew the challenges were great, but he also knew that this community had endured much worse. And when all was said and done, he hoped to look back and see that, even in the face of darkness, there was light.

The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 The Czech tennis player Jana Novotná, who has died of cancer aged 49, had a career of consistent success that would have more than satisfied most players, but fell some way short of what she would have achieved had she possessed a much steadier nerve. In 1998, the year before she retired, Novotná became only the fifth female player to pass the $10m mark in career prize money and in the same year was within reach of being ranked No 1 in the world. As an athlete she was among the best of her era, possessed of consummate skill in the dying and difficult art of serve-and-volley and an ability to deliver a backhand smash that was the envy of her peers. And yet in her 14 years at the top of the women’s game she won only 24 tour singles titles. Even more disappointingly, she reached the last eight in 22 of the 50 grand slam singles events in which she competed but managed to convert that consistency into just one title. The American player and commentator Pam Shriver, who was a good friend, explained this by saying that Novotná was “as kind as she was athletic”. Others, mostly tennis writers such as myself, put it more brutally: she was a choker. Novotná herself said she hated the idea of choking, preferring instead to say that she “got a little tight”. Her most famous episode of getting a little tight is now a case study for sports psychologists. It came in the 1993 Wimbledon final when she led Steffi Graf 6-7, 6-1, 4-1, and at 40-30 in the sixth game of the deciding set had a service point for a 5-1 lead over the German.
-------

She was a master of the serve-and-volley style, a technique that required precision, timing, and courage. Her ability to deliver a backhand smash that left her opponents in awe was a hallmark of her game. However, despite her talent, her career achievements fell slightly short of what might have been, not because of a lack of ability, but because of a tendency to choke under pressure—a term often used to describe her struggles during critical moments in big matches.
