This feat spoke volumes about her consistency and the impact she had made on the sport. That same year, she was narrowly losing the race for the world No. 1 ranking to Martina Hingis. Yet, her dominance on the court was undeniable. She won the Wimbledon, US Open, and Australian Open titles, amassing 24 tour singles titles in her 14 years at the top. But what was even more surprising was her ability to reach the last eight in 22 out of 50 Grand Slam singles events she competed in—achievements that often led to disappoinment, as she managed to win just one title.  

SECTION 3  
Novotná’s struggle with nerve was a well-documented part of her career. Pam Shriver, her close friend and a former ESPN analyst, described her as “as kind as she was athletic,” emphasizing her warmth and integrity off the court. However, on the court, she was often criticized for her inability to handle the psychological demands of the game. Journalists and analysts, including herself, avoided using the word “choking,” instead preferring to say she “got a little tight” when under pressure. One of the most famous episodes of her career occurred during the 1993 Wimbledon final, when she was leading Steffi Graf 6-7, 6-1, 4-1, and was serving at 40-30 in the sixth game of the deciding set. Wanting to give her a 5-1 lead, Novotná double-faulted, and the match slipped away, leaving her to wonder what could have been.

The 1993 Wimbledon final remains a defining moment in Novotná’s career—a moment where her mental strength was tested like never before. However, a series of unforced errors cost her the match, and she ultimately lost in straight sets—a bitter pill to swallow. This moment of glory turned into heartbreak, and it became a case study for sports psychologists to understand the complexities of the mental game. Despite her best efforts, Novotná often struggled to translate her undeniable skill into victory in high-stakes matches, leaving her with a legacy that felt incomplete.  

SECTION 5  
Jana Novotná’s legacy is one of a tennis player who was ahead of her time and yet hindered by her own fears and insecurities. She was a model athlete, both on and off the court, earning the respect of her peers and fans worldwide. Despite only one Grand Slam title, her ability to reach the later stages of so many tournaments speaks to her enduring competitive spirit. Yet, her failure to win more titles, coupled with her public struggles with nerve, left some wondering whether she had reached her full potential. However, Novotná herself never complained. She accepted her lot with grace, preferring to focus on the joy of playing the game she loved. In the end, it was her honesty and humility that left an indelible mark on the sport, as well as the haunting memory of the opportunities she let slip away. Jana Novotná may not have achieved the grandest of victories, but her courage, skill, and humanity made her a champion of her era—a player whose story continues to inspire those who believed in her, even when she believed in herself the least.

turns:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 EasyJet saw its profits fall 17% last year, with more than £100m lost due to the slump in the pound after the Brexit vote. The airline reported a record year for passenger numbers, flying 80.2 million people, almost 10% more than in 2015-16, on ever fuller planes. But while revenues exceeded £5bn in 2016-17, fares dipped to fill seats in what the chief executive, Carolyn McCall, said was “a difficult year for the aviation industry”. McCall said: “Our planned approach of achieving number one or two positions at Europe’s leading airports, friendly and efficient customer service and a continuous focus on sustainable cost control, has put easyJet at a strategic advantage during a period when there have been bankruptcies and some airlines have struggled operationally.” Profits before tax fell from £494m to £408m. Despite paying a lower dollar price for fuel, the continued weakness of sterling brought additional costs of £101m, easyJet said. The airline will also be prompted by Brexit to change its rules to ensure easyJet is majority owned and controlled by EU nationals after 2019. About a third of shares are owned by the easyJet founder, Stelios Haji-Ioannou, who has dual UK-Cypriot nationality, and will be classed as EU-owned. But easyJet will ask at its 2018 AGM for new powers to force UK shareholders to sell up if necessary to allow it to continue operating in Europe. McCall said the move was “a technical, administrative thing” and the airline had “no concerns” about getting enough EU shareholders. Shares rose by more than 5% in early trading, on the back of the airline reporting high levels of forward bookings and better revenue so far in its 2017-18 financial year, which it said was “primarily as a result of some capacity leaving the market”.
-------

response:
The microbiome, a complex ecosystem of trillions of bacteria in the gut, is as vital to human health as the hormonal or brain systems. Atlas, a British company, categorizes gut microbiomes into three types: the Urban Citizen, the Village Peasant, and the Indigene. These categories are determined by diet and lifestyle. The Urban Citizen is associated with Western diets—cinnamon toast and KFC—but the Village Peasant is seen as more beneficial, linked to an ancient, healthier way of life.

In August, I paid £125 for a gut microbiome test, a process that involved catching my poo on a piece of paper. The results? I’m a Village Peasant. This meant I had bacteria like Dorea genus, which reduces gut inflammation, lowering my risk of Crohn’s disease. My high consumption of Ovaltine—probably a substitute for bananas—aligns with the bacteria’s growth.

At first, I was dismissive of my peasant status, joking about my “dumpy” appearance. But the more I read, the more I realized the value of my Village Peasant microbiome. It suggested a healthier, more sustainable lifestyle. My body worked in harmony with the bacteria, rather than against it.

I mentioned the test results to my friends, who were curious but skeptical. Some laughed, calling it a trendy fad. others showed interest. I explained the science: our gut is not just a stomach—it’s a sophisticated ecosystem that impacts everything from immunity to mental health. The bacteria in my gut, particularly eubacterium, were proof of a balanced microbiome.

One evening, as I listened to a playlist of classical music, I felt a sense of calm. Maybe it was the Ovaltine, or maybe it was the realization that I was finally in control of my health. I decided to stick with my Village Peasant habits, despite the ridiculing remarks from friends who still smoked and ate whatever they wanted.

The value of my microbiome wasn’t just about the bacteria; it was about the lifestyle it encouraged—a slower, more intentional way of living. I wasn’t chasing the Indigene or the Urban Citizen; I had my own path. And I was content with it.

turns:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 The campaign group that encouraged Paperchase to apologise for its marketing activities with the Daily Mail is pushing for John Lewis, the department store chain, to stop advertising with the newspaper as well as with the Sun and Daily Express. John Lewis has become a prime target for Stop Funding Hate on the back of the launch of its Christmas advert and as retailers increase their spending on advertising as the festive season approaches. Stop Funding Hate has produced a mock advert that depicts the star of last year’s John Lewis Christmas advert – Buster the dog – as unhappy because the retailer is buying adverts with the Mail, Sun, and Express. The video has been shared almost 10,000 times on Twitter and Facebook. Sainsbury’s, Marks & Spencer and Waitrose are also being targeted by Stop Funding Hate. The organisation was founded last year and says its aim is to take on “divisive hate campaigns” by the Mail, Sun and Express, and persuade advertisers to cease their financial input. Richard Wilson, the founder of Stop Funding Hate, said: “[John Lewis] are a company well known for their ethical values and one that people have a lot of respect for. Customers are saying there is a clash between what the brand stands for and these newspapers. It would be great if John Lewis made a move, but another company could make a move too.” However, John Lewis said it would continue advertising with the newspapers and not bow to the pressure. A spokesperson said: “Withdrawing advertising on the basis of editorial coverage would be inconsistent with our democratic principles, which include freedom of speech and remaining apolitical.” Paperchase announced on Monday that it would not run any marketing campaigns with the Daily Mail and said it was “truly sorry” for running a front-page promotion in Saturday’s edition of the newspaper.
-------

response:
Classic campaigns for social change often begin with a spark of protest, and this one is no different. The group Stop Funding Hate, known for its flap at Paperchase, is now doubling down on its mission, targeting John Lewis in a bid to cut ties with the Daily Mail, Sun, and Express. The group’s latest move? A mock advert featuring Buster the dog, the star of last year’s Christmas campaign, looking gloomy over John Lewis’s decision to advertise with these publications. The video, shared nearly 10,000 times on Twitter and Facebook, aims to amplify the message: John Lewis, a retailer synonymous with ethics, is aligning itself with outlets known for divisive coverage. This has déjà vu all around, as Stop Funding Hate also has its sights set on Sainsbury’s, Marks & Spencer, and Waitrose.

Stop Funding Hate emerged last year, its sole mission to disrupt what it calls “divisive hate campaigns” by the Mail, Sun, and Express. Richard Wilson, the group’s founder, emphasizes that his intention isn’t to bash these companies but to persuade them to stop financially supporting outlets that spread misinformation or divisive rhetoric. “Consumers are saying there’s a clash between what the brand stands for and these newspapers,” Wilson explains. “It would be great if John Lewis made a move, but another company could make a move too.” Yet, as the festive season approaches and retailers crank up their advertising budgets, the pressure is on for brands to choose their alliances wisely.

Despite the backlash, John Lewis has refused to budge. A spokesperson for the company stated that pulling ads over editorial content is “inconsistent with our democratic principles,” which include the freedom of speech and an apolitical stance. This decision has divided opinions, with some praising John Lewis for steadfastness and others criticizing its alignment with newspapers known for controversial reporting. Meanwhile, Paperchase’s recent about-face—announcing the cessation of its marketing ties with the Daily Mail—and its public apology have set a precedent. As the debate rages on, the question looms: can brands truly remain neutral in a world consumed by polarized media?
